Award.AwardTitle: Multidimensional Hypergeometric Functions and Quantum Integrable Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research is directed to developing relations between commutative algebras appearing in several fields: the algebra of Hamiltonians of a quantum integrable system, the algebra of functions on an intersection of Schubert varieties in a flag variety, the quantum cohomology algebra of a flag variety, the chiral ring of an N = 2 supersymmetric gauge theory, the local algebra of a critical point in singularity theory. All those algebras are related to the ring of functions on the critical set of the master function (or superpotential) associated with a given situation. Developing these relations will be important and useful for each of the fields and will enrich their interaction.

Multidimensional hypergeometric integrals and their semiclassical limits, Bethe eigenfunctions and eigenvectors appear as solutions to differential and difference equations in quantum integrable systems, representation theory, algebraic geometry, gauge theory, statistical mechanics. The equations and solutions have rich mathematical structures. The multidimensional hypergeometric integrals provide a way to transform the objects and structures of those theories to objects and structures of geometry and analysis of master functions and weight functions associated with the integrals. The goal of the proposal is to develop this analysis and geometry with applications to the above theories. That will lead to better understanding of interrelations of those theories as well as to establishing new connections among them. The PI has incorporated results of his prior research into graduate courses and expects to do the same again. His graduate students and students from neighboring universities will also be involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was directed to developing relations between commutative algebras appearing in several fields of mathematics and physics: the algebra of Hamiltonians of a quantum integrable system, the algebra of functions on an intersection of Schubert varieties in a flag variety, the quantum cohomology algebra of a flag variety, the chiral ring of a  supersymmetric gauge theory, the local algebra of a critical point in singularity theory.  All those algebras are related to the ring of functions on the critical set of the master function (or superpotential) associated with a given situation. The results of the project are useful for each of the fields and enrich their interaction.  Among such results are the interpretation of the algebra of quantum multiplication on the equivariant cohomology of the cotangent bundle of a partial flag variety as the algebra of functions on the fibers of a discrete Wronky map; the interpretation of the equivariant K-theory algebra of the cotangent bundle of a partial flag variety as a Bethe algebra of the XXZ model; the construction of multidimensional hypergeometric solutions of the quantum differential equation associated with the cotangent bundle of a partial flag variety; the establishment of the mKdV flows on the critical set of master functions associated with affine Lie algebras.

The algebras of Hamiltonians of quantum integrable systems,  the quantum cohomology algebras, the chiral rings of supersymmetric gauge theories appear in the theory of quantum  integrable systems, representation theory, algebraic geometry, gauge theory, statistical mechanics. The multidimensional hypergeometric integrals and associated master functions provide a way to transform the objects and structures of those theories into objects and structures  of the geometry and analysis of master functions and weight functions associated with the integrals. The results of the project are developing these analysis and geometry with applications to the above theories.  The results lead to better understanding the interrelations between those parts of mathematics and physics as well as to establishing new connections among them.

The results of this project were published by the PI in more than twenty research papers.  While developing this project, the PI supervised three graduate students, who became coauthors of research papers. The PI conducted at UNC the seminar ”Physically Inspired Mathematics” where UNC graduate students and students from neighboring universities  were exposed to current research problems, in particular to problems of this project.
